Title: Posterior parietal cortex in Rhesus monkey: I. Parcellation of areas based on distinctive limbic and sensory corticocortical connections
Comments: This article reports parietal, temporal + occipital label from the same experiments as in the companion paper CG89b.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "In order to respect historical precedents and yet incorporate more recent data, we have adopted the following simplified terminology for the subdivisions of Brodmann's area 7: area 7m, located on the medial surface of the hemisphere; areas 7a and 7b, on the convexity of the posterior parietal lobe; and area 7ip, in the posterior bank of IpS (Fig. 2)." (p. 396)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Areas 7a and 7b were first recognized by the Vogts (1919) and correspond to areas PG and PF of von Bonin and Bailey ... " (p. 399)
"Areas 7a and 7b were first recognized by the Vogts (1919) and correspond to areas PG and PF of von Bonin and Bailey ... " (p. 399)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: As CG89a-MTp is defined according to UD86b, it seems likely that the same is true for MT.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "... a narrow strip of granular retrosplenial cortex (Vogt, 1976) also contained heavy concentrations of anterograde and retrograde labeling (Figs. 3a, 4, 16c)." (p. 401)

"This labeled region seems to correspond to the posterior part of visual area PO (Covey et al., 1982; Colby et al., 1988) and to the part of V2 lying on the floor of the parieto-occipital sulcus (Gattas et al., 1981)... " (p. 405) " ... dense labeling was found in ... several physiologically defined visual areas, including V4, V3v (also termed VP, Burkhalter et al., 1986; Gattas et al., 1988) and V2 (Gattas et al., 1981, 1985; Ungerleider and Desimone, 1986)." (p. 405)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: GGS81 is a standard reference for defining area V2.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Zeki 1978a as cited here corresponds to Z78b in this database.

"In order to respect historical precedents and yet incorporate more recent data, we have adopted the following simplified terminology for the subdivisions of Brodmann's area 7: area 7m, located on the medial surface of the hemisphere; areas 7a and 7b, on the convexity of the posterior parietal lobe; and area 7ip, in the posterior bank of IpS (Fig. 2)." "In order to respect historical precedents and yet incorporate more recent data, we have adopted the following simplified terminology for the subdivisions of Brodmann's area 7: area 7m, located on the medial surface of the hemisphere; areas 7a and 7b, on the convexity of the posterior parietal lobe; and area 7ip, in the posterior bank of IpS (Fig. 2)." (p. 396)

"In order to respect historical precedents and yet incorporate more recent data, we have adopted the following simplified terminology for the subdivisions of Brodmann's area 7: area 7m, located on the medial surface of the hemisphere; areas 7a and 7b, on the convexity of the posterior parietal lobe; and area 7ip, in the posterior bank of IpS (Fig. 2)." (p. 396)
"Area 7m corresponds to Von Bonin and Bailey's (1947) medial area PE ... " (pp. 396-399)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
This article wrongly states that von Bonin and Bailey (1947) believed their area PE to be a subpart of Brodmann's area 5. In their original account, von Bonin & Bailey clearly point out (BB47, pp. 36, 72) that (i) area PE contains two parts, an anterior PEm, and a posterior part PEp, (ii) that PEm is part of Brodmann's area 5 (p. 36), (iii) that PEp is part of Brodmann's area 7 (p. 72).
Nevertheless, the above statement of CG89a of CG89a-7m being a subarea of BB47-PE is still correct.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "... the upper bank of the posterior superior temporal sulcus (STS) ... has commonly been considered part of parietal area 7a ... recent studies indicate that this part of STS contains two visual areas (the peripheral middle temporal area, MTp, and the medial superior temporal area, MST) that are involved in the visual analysis of motion, and are interconnected with area MT and other visual cortices (Maunsell and Van Essen, 1983; Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986; Ungerleider and Desimone, 1986)."

"... the upper bank of the posterior superior temporal sulcus (STS) ... has commonly been considered part of parietal area 7a ... recent studies indicate that this part of STS contains two visual areas (the peripheral middle temporal area, MTp, and the medial superior temporal area, MST) that are involved in the visual analysis of motion, and are interconnected with area MT and other visual cortices (Maunsell and Van Essen, 1983; Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986; Ungerleider and Desimone, 1986)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: In the citation above, both MV83 and UD86b are listed as potential for the definition of MTp: however, MTp is not known yet by MV83, but is defined by UD86a, UD86b, and DU86.

@Injections.Citation:
"Trititated amino acids were also injected in 7a in case 3. The injection was confined to the posterior half of the posterior parietal lobe (Fig. 9d) ... Because of technical reasons, autoradiographic sections through several parts of the brain were not available for analysis. Where present, however, the findings confirmed those observed with HRP-WGA and provided additional information concerning the topography of some major connections of area 7a." (p. 401)
"In case 3, tritiated amino acids were also injected in 7a. The injection was placed in the anterior half of 7a, sparing the posterior half."
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "The injection site in the medial parietal cortex was situated below and posterior to the caudal tip of the cingulate sulcus (Figs. 2, 3c, 4), and lay well within the boundaries of area 7m. The needle tracks, which were oriented parallel to the pial surface, were located between the superficial and deep layers of the cortex. There was no evidence of involvement of the subjacent white matter, or of neighbouring cortical areas, by the HRP reaction product." (p. 399)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: p. 399: "Dense anterograde and retrograde label was also observed caudally in the anterior parietal lobe and adjacent superficial cortex of the anterior bank of posterior IpS ..."  The following reference to BB47 indicates that PEm is labeled.

p. 399: "Dense anterograde and retrograde label was also observed caudally in the anterior parietal lobe and adjacent superficial cortex of the anterior bank of posterior IpS ..."  The following reference to BB47 indicates that PEm is labeled.

@Injections.Citation: "In case 2, the HRP-WGA injection was placed in the caudal one-third of the posterior parietal lobe and included the posterior part of area 7a (Figs. 2, 6e, 7, 8c). It extended onto the adjacent cortex of the upper bank of posterior STS and onto the lip of the posterior bank of IpS. The most medial needle track was entirely confined within the cortical layers, but the deepest part of the lateral track was situated at the boundary between layer VI and the white matter. As a consequence, HRP reaction product spread in the upper 2 mm of the white matter underlying the anterior part of the injection site (Fig. 6d).  The pattern of labeling obtained in this case is not likely due to uptake of the tracer by fibers of passage of cortical regions other than posterior area 7a. The white matter interrupted by the injection is at the vertex of the funneled shaped junction of the intraparietal and lunate sulci, thus containing mainly fibers that link area 7a with other brain regions. In addition, the pattern of results in this case did not differ essentially from other reports of lateral parietal projections in the literature ..." (p. 401)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation:
"The injection of HRP-WGA in case 3 was situated in the convexity of the anterior half of the posterior parietal lobe (area 7b; Figs. 2, 9C, 10, 11A, 12A). In its most anterior part, it extended slightly onto the adjacent superficial part of the posterior bank of IpS. There was no evidence of involvement of the underlying white matter by the needle tracks." (p. 403, CG89a)
"The HRP-WGA injection was placed in the anterior half of the posterior parietal lobe, within area 7b, with no involvement of the underlying white matter or of neighboring areas." (p. 435, CG89b)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "The injection in case 4 was the largest in the series and spanned areas 7a and 7b (Fig. 2). However, the most anterior, most posterior, and most lateral parts of the posterior parietal lobe were not included within the injection area. Two of the needle tracks, in the most medial part of the posterior parietal convexity, traversed the border between the cortex and the white matter but were no deeper than 1 mm from this border. Sections through the anteroposterior extent of the central sulcus and through the occipital lobe were not processed." (p. 403)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "Connections of area 7ip (cases 5 and 6): In both cases 5 and 6, the HRP-WGA injections were situated at the middle rostrocaudal level of the posterior bank of IpS, involving the superficial three-fourths of the bank and sparing the deeper one-fourth (Figs. 2, 13c, 14, 15) ... In case 6, the deepest end of one needle track was situated at the boundary between the cortex and the white matter. The findings in both cases were essentially similar, and therefore we describe and illustrate here those of case 5." (p. 405)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In the hemisphere opposite to the injection, the heaviest labeling was found in area 7ip (Figs. 13, 14, 18G). In addition, anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the cingulate cortex, area 7m, occipitotemporal sulcus, STS (Fig. 18H), and the inferior temporal and dorsal prelunate gyri (Figs. 13, 14)." (p. 405)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Neither the description above nor the figures allow to determine easily in what areas the label within the STS and occipitotemporal sulcus is located. I have thus refrained from interpreting this label.

publication.title: Posterior parietal cortex in Rhesus monkey: I. Parcellation of areas based on distinctive limbic and sensory corticocortical connections
